title: Thursday, 18th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Morning! Hello, welcome, hi, hey there.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Mouselet Good morning assorted and miscellaneous people
GBKrona Hola
BE11:02am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this thing.

Soundbuy Morning all.............
Tom Dalgleish Hey
BE11:03am

And it's going to be quite corporate this morning. We have a Thursday-ish amount of corporate news around, but not much else.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Also, I'm pleased to day that Dan joins me.

DM11:04am

Morning!

BE11:04am

Thumbs up

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Right. Stupid picture to get us rolling.

BE11:04am

ValencianBull morning
BE11:04am

Brexit lager. On sale at B&M, I'm told.

11:04 am
DM11:04am

Looks like a pound shop lable

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 415.70, down 1.3 (-0.31%), High: 419.00, Low: 415.30, Volume: 554.99k
DM11:05am

52 per cent abv?

Mouselet not at a pound per third-of-a-litre!
Mouselet I don't think even brewdog got to 52% for beer-like substance
Pharma @DM, pound shops always leave off the price (to confuse their customers)
11:05 am
BE11:06am

That's one of the many jokes that more or less write themselves. You can play with the themes of "bitter" and "hangover" and "imperial pint" as well.

doeswalk I think I can see 4.6 on the label
Mouselet (the '12.6P FOR 1 LITRE' looks a bit dodgy to me)
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Ship's company!
sprout shouldn't they be selling it in pint bottles?
Fox Shire - what's going on?
BE11:06am

Feel free to crack wise, ROTR.

undefined
Mouselet I think that is dodgy
11:06 am
DM11:07am

So, anything happening?

Lemmy It's a lager, surely it ought to be an ale?
Mouselet brexitbeverages.com has closed down, for example
BE11:07am

(@Fox: nothing, otherwise they'd have had to tell us. How many times do I have to say that?)

Mouselet The DJIA is soaring like some kind of auspicious albatross
Mouselet Kittens exist and some of them have big fluffy ears
BE11:07am

Um ............ I guess we can go straight to the warnings.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Of which Countrywide is the most notable.

Mouselet on what index is countrywide? BBC were reporting 'down 15%' and then it didn't appear in their tables of companies
Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 112.80, down 22.4 (-16.57%), High: 114.60, Low: 110.00, Volume: 523.74k
Lemmy Mouselet: maybe that's why the lot is being discounted at B&M?
DM11:08am

ouch, trouble in estate agent land

Pharma @Mouselet, the brewery closing down is presumably why it has ended up at B&M.
Mouselet ah yes
11:08 am
BE11:08am

So -- full-year revenue is a big miss against consensus. £672m vs £698m expected.

DM11:09am

Didn't it use to be a £7 stock?

Mouselet I am still suspicious about the various shades of yellow and the obviously wrong price per litre on the label, it would be odd if B&M routinely violate that bit of customer protection law?
Mouselet 686p on 14 March 2014
Flaneur CWD down but the property pollyannas at reuters report a 'pick up' from 4 year lows on RICS. Dont recall them reporting falls for the last for year though....
DJ 3yr low for Shire now?
BE11:10am

It did, I think. But the idea that transaction volumes would be resilient, or just recover, hasn't really played out.

Mouselet ah yes, CWD fell out of the FTSE250 end of 2016
Flaneur Its almost as though falls in property prices cannot be reported.... or something...
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Ebitda also misses, at £65m vs £71.5m consensus.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Brexit Beer - £350 million per litre
BE11:11am

And that's drawing rather a lot of attention to the debt, which looks ..... bad.

BE11:11am

Here's UBS:

doeswalk companies house website not working properly :(
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Net debt of c.£193m of the FY implies a leverage ratio of 3.0x, which means that the near-term balance sheet risk remains given no evidence of a turn-around in the business to date.

Fox Shire - 4 year low
BE11:11am

Divisionally Sales & Lettings saw the greatest weakness with revenues down -14% (including UK -17%, London -10%), and EBITDA down -45%. Elsewhere B2B EBITDAd increase 14% to £36m, with Financial Services down -12% to £20m.

Flaneur Brexit beer @£1 for 330ml would be fairly hi end for B&M
Pharma @Flaneur, don't get me started on the "6% more of our members saw rising prices than saw price falls" nonsense. RICS tells you nothing quantitatively useful about house prices.
Fox NATIONAL GRID - 5 YEAR LOWS
DM11:13am

Net debt is down, but still rather a lot for a company with about 15 competitors on every high street

Flaneur @Pharma - I think thats the point. The amount of people (and media reports) which deliberately report this as 6% rise in house prices is frightening.
Mouselet Four-and-a-bit year lows, 825p on 13/12/2013
Mouselet (sorry, I don't think I'm adding information to this conversation)
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Yep. Particularly given the suggestion today that trading is still getting worse rather than better.

DM11:13am

And slowly tightening rules on not being, can I say total gits? to customers

DM11:14am

For the industry, obvs, the much loved industry

Tom Dalgleish An Aussie listed RE agent McGrath tumbled a similar amount for same reasons. There are patterns.............
11:14 am
BE11:15am

And also the new entrants. We can debate for some time whether the online types and hybrids actually sell houses, but the important point is that estate agency is simply a volume game, and the volumes aren't there for an ever expanding pool of competition.

Fox Why do share buybacks almost always cause a crash in the share price? NG, WPP, KGF examples. Smacks of blatant manipulation IMO and reflects very poorly on the market.
Mouselet why in the eighty thousand Hells do you have to borrow money to be an estate agent ???
BE11:15am

Here's Peel Hunt:

BE11:15am

The outlook remains challenging with little or no uplift in transactions expected in 2018. The group has taken further actions to restore the sales and lettings business to profitable growth, however, as 2017 has shown, it has been difficult to predict the profit impact of a reduction in the branch network footprint/costs. Headwinds remain for the lettings business, albeit, the timing of the implementation of the Government’s lettings fee ban has been pushed back to 2019. When it comes into force, we are forecasting a c£15m profit impact from the fee ban, largely offsetting ongoing cost-cutting measures.

Pharma @Flaneur, but the proportion of people who understand that a -ve RICS number is consistent with rising prices (and vice versa) is so small it makes even straight reporting unintentionally disingenuous.
Mouselet Your assets are a random office on a high street somewhere and some chirpy salespeople, and for this people every so often pay you 3% of the cost of a house
Flaneur I take it we've all brushed up on our diplomatic etiquette as here - https://pbs.twimg.com/media/C_6kx8yVwAEdWvH.jpg
11:15 am
BE11:16am

Forecasting revenues and profits for Countrywide
remains tricky due to the turbulent trading backdrop, ongoing cost cutting measures and the shifting expectation on the timing of the lettings fee ban. Overall, we expect the backdrop to remain challenging, with no material improvement in profits expected in the current year. The relatively high gearing also remains a concern for a business operating in a highly cyclical industry. On current forecasts, the shares trade on a FY18 PE of 9.8x with EV/EBITDA of 6.6x and a dividend yield of 1.5%. We maintain our Reduce recommendation.

DM11:16am

Rest of UK down much harder than London, which is still down a tenth. Will be interesting to watch how that plays out this year.

Pharma @Mouselet, and Apple borrows huge amounts because...?
DM11:17am

(@Mouselet - private equity. Apollo & Oaktree)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The entire UK housing market is so weird, from the planning committees to the builders to the estate agents to the mortgage lenders. No one in their right mind would design the system to work this way.

BE11:17am

Anyway, sector ............

Kiwi-juice UK real estate agent fees are so much lower than on the continent. Quite a mystery me to why 1) they are lower or 2) the continent is so high
Foxtons Group PLC (FOXT:LSE): Last: 78.00, down 4 (-4.88%), High: 79.70, Low: 75.00, Volume: 132.34k
hornblower CWD raised £36m equity at 175p to cut debt earlier this year
11:18 am
Savills PLC (SVS:LSE): Last: 986.00, down 3 (-0.30%), High: 992.00, Low: 981.50, Volume: 35.77k
BE11:18am

(Though Savills isn't really a peer, of course.)

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 422.80, up 18.6 (+4.60%), High: 425.00, Low: 397.80, Volume: 817.76k
11:18 am
BE11:19am

(Likewise Purplebricks, which is its own little enigma.)

Pharma Higher in the US too (6%), but that is because buyers all engage an agent, and the fee is split 50:50. Makes for a better informed market.
undefined
DM11:19am

Bit of Macro?

Mouselet I think I am willing to take a badly-informed market in return for not having to pay ten thousand pounds for very little every time I move house!
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Yes! Please.

DM11:19am

Remember Greece, small country, lot of debt

BE11:20am

Vaguely.

11:20 am
DM11:20am

bond market getting a bit enthusiastic this week, lowest yields since I think September

Tom Dalgleish @Pharma so much better informed before sub-prime crisis
Shinshin US agents are more on the hook legally than UK I think
DM11:20am

Mujtaba Rahman at the Eurasia group getting excited about the IMF

casapinos @kiwi in France agents have major responsibilities for misdescription and carry much more insurance
DM11:21am

(He has a good line in emails, if you aren't signed up)

11:21 am
DM11:21am

In a bizarre and unexpected turn of events, the odds are increasing that the IMF will officially join the third Greek bailout prior to its conclusion on 20 August.

DM11:21am

It is all to do with politics elsewhere

DM11:22am

Most important, there is a growing recognition among the IMF’s leadership that the “universe does not revolve around Greece” and that the institution risks being isolated if it crashes out of the Greek program. This is especially important given difficult relations with US President Donald Trump. An antagonistic relationship with the EU would leave the institution estranged from its two principal shareholders—in a worst-case scenario, even jeopardizing its funding.

Pharma @Tom, true their was the collective delusion that "prices never fall", but I think the US market corrected faster, and more rationally than the UK one.
hornblower BE do you have the JPM note on PURP?
11:22 am
DM11:22am

Christine Lagarde seems “to have seen the light”. More realistically, the IMF’s instinct for self-preservation is contributing to a different approach. IMF staff have now started to play nice with their EU counterparts, and are seriously considering activating their program. This is, however, still far from a done deal. As we’ve long argued, the Eurogroup will not grant debt relief to Greece that moves beyond the parameters of the 15 June 2017 deal

DM11:23am

There is a lot of depth about the programmes etc, but lets see if we can find a bottom line

wayneJ I was looking at some London properties yesterday - some developers seem to price 'luxuriously'
DM11:24am

Our long-held view is that Greece will successfully exit its program in August, and enter into “enhanced surveillance” under the EU’s two-pack

Tom Dalgleish @Pharma I did some research and found in the USA there is quite a history of borrowers besieging banks until the loan is forgiven
11:24 am
DM11:24am

This could indeed be called a “clean exit”—as Greece will not be receiving any financing from its European partners. At the same time, Athens will not simply revert to the “European semester”—the system of top-down economic surveillance that applies to other EU member states on fiscal policy (via the Stability and Growth Pact) and broader macro policy (via the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure). There will of course be a degree of intrusion by the Eurogroup that is more substantial—but that does not mean Greece’s exit is not “clean”.

DM11:25am

Debt relief now on the table in Berlin again, and domestic situation also looks good

DM11:26am

Greece’s domestic context also favours a successful exit this year. An omnibus bill tabled by the government last week to close the third review included two very controversial provisions but was passed with relative ease—securing not only 153 votes from coalition MPs but an extra vote from an independent MP Theodora Megalooikonomou, who has subsequently joined the Syriza parliamentary group.

Pharma @DM, in all this talk about clean exits, do they happen to mention when the IMF and ECB will get their money back?
11:26 am
DM11:26am

That should do us. TL:DR, Greece is fine

BE11:26am

Thumbs up

chopper bear on a side note watched the darkest hour last night - well worth a watch
DM11:27am

(@Pharma, steady on. Fine = not crashing out of the euro in flames, maybe raising new debt in the market)

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

So, to sellside.

BE11:27am

And @Hornblower reminds me that I should've noted above that there's a JPM initiation on Purplebricks this morning.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Overweight, 733p target.

BE11:28am

I've only glanced through but it's ..... quite a straightforward bit of analysis.

DM11:28am

go on

11:28 am
BE11:29am

"Here are the numbers they're doing and if they also do numbers similar to those numbers in the future on other places it'll have a lot of money."

BE11:29am

I guess you can see it as a companion piece to the more granular stuff from the likes of Jefferies, that ponders stuff like completion rates etc.

BE11:29am

Here's the upshot.

Blank canvas AA plc?
Optimist Aa plc?
11:29 am
BE11:30am

UK-based Purplebricks is the dominant player in the relatively new segment of online property agents (with the company having a c.75% market share in the segment). Purplebricks runs a hybrid model with its propriety technology offering home sellers an online service for the entire process of buying and selling properties. Further, the company also offers home sellers a growing network of Local Property Experts (LPEs) who provide a full service estate agency offering for a fixed fee and – most importantly – at a fraction of the cost of traditional high street agents. On our estimates, the average fee is about 70% lower than with a traditional agent. Purplebricks was only launched in 2014 and has already become the largest estate agent in the UK (by number of instructions).

BE11:30am

The future of online agents appears bright – we expect a 15% market share for Purplebricks in the UK by 2022 (versus around 6-7% today) Purplebricks’ low fixed costs (its labour costs are more variable than for traditional agents as all LPEs are self-employed and the company does not incur similar property costs to thehigh street agent) provide significant cost advantages which allows it to charge a significantly lower price. We estimate Purplebricks to take 15% market share by 2022 (versus c.6-7% today). We expect growing awareness and understanding of the Purplebricks’ offering to drive more valuation enquiries, which then are converting to new instructions and, as a result, high revenue growth.

DM11:30am

"by number of instructions"

Soundbuy Aye AA. off 7.5%......wheels coming off..........requires a recovery service IMO
Shinshin @chopper - earlier version of Brexit ?
11:31 am
BE11:31am

It's the only measure we can use, really, unless Purplebricks wants to give us number of competitions.

BE11:31am

Which they're welcome to! They know our number!

DM11:31am

Funny that they prefer not to

FitzLions 4th most read article on the FT this morning is... the Crossword. Slow news day.
11:31 am
BE11:32am

Yeah. Odd.

BE11:32am

On international expansion .......

BE11:32am

Following its strong success in the UK, Purplebricks has also launched its service in
Australia (Q416) and the US (Q417) with the latter being the largest property market globally. The Australian market is relatively similar to the UK with two established property portals, and Purplebricks has a first-mover advantage (no other sizable online agent is currently active). The US clearly provides a significant opportunity – initially, the company will start in the biggest market, California, but says it is likely to further expand into six other states in the short term.

wayneJ @BE - I suspect you mean 'number of completions' - unless we have all misunderstood the PURP model and it is indeed about gambling the prospects of a sale? (You wrote 'number of competitions' :-) )
chopper bear pretty persistent selling with shire this week
11:33 am
DM11:33am

Probably taking the Amazon approach, you don't need to know the number, puny investor, which reminds me

DM11:33am

In the US market Realtors take 6 per cent of a sale

DM11:34am

3 from buyer and seller, which is split if the buyer has a broker too, because Americans

11:34 am
BE11:34am

(@wayneJ: heh. My typing's Murphy-bad this morning.)

wayneJ One might think that fundamental research would involve investigating whether the customer gets value for money and a fair deal. And whether a business model is subject to a specific quirk in regulation which is of questionable validity.
Tom Dalgleish Wouldn't it be good if spellcheck if grammar too
DM11:35am

And when it comes to internet competition, there is a name which hedgies like to throw around as the arch competitor which might enter the market

BE11:35am

Yeah, the dual agency structure in the US is even sillier than ours.

Tom Dalgleish *did grammar LOL
11:35 am
DM11:36am

Based in Seattle, conquers all. Has developed an internet lock for package delivery that might also work to let prospective buyers into a house for sale

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian If you think the UK and US is bad you should try Belgium!
Mouselet Spain too
DM11:36am

There was a brief flurry back in the summer of a possible page to display listings. But nothing since, so it may never happen

Mouselet (I think it cost something like 10% of the face value for my brother to buy a Madrid flat)
BE11:37am

(@tonyb: sorry but I'm deleting that comment. Can you rephrase it in a way that we don't have to pass to the lawyer?)

Tom Dalgleish Funny how our word memories are poetic
11:37 am
DM11:37am

"Alexa, is the seller in a chain?"

wayneJ You blink and the world changes.....and images are now dreams....
Tom Dalgleish @Mouse Ive seen countries at 25% for the round trip, plus or minus 5%
DM11:37am

Anyway, we were talking about Purplebricks

ValencianBull madrid real estate prices are "very" cheap compared to other European capitals
BE11:38am

We were, and your arguments about the ripe-for-disruption-ness of the US are entirely valid.

Tom Dalgleish PURP gonna need an army of lobbyists
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Whether that disruption comes from Purplebricks or, say, Amazon .... who knows? JP Morgan makes a stab at it.

BE11:39am

we assume an initial roll-out of the Purplebricks business
model in the largest seven states in the US in the next three years (beginning with
California) which combined saw 1.6m housing transactions in 2017. We assume that
the average house price across these seven states is $300k. Also, we assume that –
similar to the US and Australia – prevailing instruction fees for Purplebricks are well
below the average commission rates in the US (of 5-6%) at c.2.0%. We assume that
Purplebricks’ market share in the 1.6m transactions goes from 0.4% in 2019E to
4.3% by 2022. With these assumptions, we assume that revenues will increase from
£30m in 2019 to £300m by 2022 with the business turning profitable in 2022.

tonyb sure - There is a risk of litigation against all agents introducing tenants to self-managing landlords who have not registered yet. It is an offence for landlords to self-manage without being registered - question is whether the likes of Purplebricks are breaking the law by not vetting landlords
BE11:39am

That kind of thing.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Oh, should say they're taking profit in Rightmove as part of the same note.

Rightmove PLC (RMV:LSE): Last: 4,446, down 115 (-2.52%), High: 4,477, Low: 4,380, Volume: 129.00k
undefined
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @BE so your 'negative stance' of Purple is because they are not allowing transparency in valuation rather than the size of opportunity?
wayneJ When is Redfin launching its business? I only ask because I assume it has not launched given a lot of UK brokers never mention it.....
11:40 am
BE11:40am

(@tonyb: thank you.)

BE11:40am

So ............ AA mentioned several times.

AA PLC (AA.:LSE): Last: 152.80, down 12.35 (-7.48%), High: 165.55, Low: 151.70, Volume: 4.76m
Pharma I read somewhere that in Italy actual prices paid were about a third higher than list, for tax reasons. May just have been the usual pandering to reader pedudices though, and I don't know anyone who has ever bought there.
tonyb Risk of class action should not be understimated! Lawyers will got after the biggest players first naturallly
Pharma (by that I mean pay difference in cash to avoid, rather than a 30% transaction tax)
11:41 am
BE11:41am

This is Barclays doing the damage.

Mouselet err, so Italian mortgages effectively require 40% deposits? I guess it explains why the bambini stay with Mum and Dad so long!
Fox AA's problem is net assets = -£2Bn
wayneJ @tonyb - I think you are referring to hygiene. You are used to people having personal hygiene so you 'assume' everyone you meet has a sense of personal hygiene. But then someone comes along that is 'apparently' the same as others but offers a cheaper service - it is only when you dig you find that they might have made some short cuts in the 'basics' (if you see what I mean)
BE11:43am

Recommendation's overweight, but contains a whole bunch of nasty predictions on recent trading and cash requirements.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I have AA shares. Maybe I got emotionally attached via the metal badges they used to have on the front of cars a long-time ago!
DM11:43am

(@Fitzlions The crossword isn't actually the fourth most read article today, that would be the Bitcoin crash. The crossword appears because it has a permanent link ft.com/crossword and the front page list captures some of that cumulative readership)

11:43 am
BE11:43am

News flow in the short term is likely to highlight current challenges, namely the need for additional investment in the business which prolongs a meaningful uplift in FCF until FY20-21e, and the negative impact cold weather may have on short-term profitability.

wayneJ Do companies have to disclose by law the court cases they have been involved in and any out of court settlements - just wondering.
Mouselet emirates buys another bunch of A380s, which is convenient
Pharma @Mouselet, don't quote me - hearsay.(This transcript will no doubt end up as the citation on a Wikipedia page about the Italian property market)
BE11:44am

We now model a £10m yoy decline in EBITDA in FY19e and include an incremental £50m of capex over FY19/20e reflecting investment in patrols, the insurance business, call centre personnel, IT and Car Genie. We also cut the dividend from our numbers; at ~7x leverage we believe this is prudent, it releases c£60m p.a. of cash and we calculate the Class A dividend covenants will mandate a reduction anyway.

Mouselet I won't put it there
CS1 @1st Lt: it wasn't because the AA patrolman used to salute you?
BE11:45am

I mean .... 7x leverage and a divi. What kind of nonsense is that?

11:45 am
DM11:45am

Another company released from the caring hands of private equity, its almost like there's a pattern

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @CS1 - oh, that too! :)
BE11:46am

Well, indeed. And it can be argued that the UK market's fetishisation of dividends is a part of the problem too.

BE11:46am

Has there been a single moment of its public life when AA should've been paying out cash to shareholders rather than degearing?

Optimist What's the TP for AA from Barc?
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Anyway, here's the kicker.

BE11:47am

There is no ‘quick-fix’ as attempts to de-lever rapidly are complicated by: 1) redeemed Class A notes require ‘make-whole’ payments covering all outstanding interest to maturity; 2) the capital raise required to lower leverage to a ‘normal’ level (we estimate c£2bn) may not be plausible.

BE11:48am

But buy anyway, remarkably.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Longer-term, we believe the equity return story and investment case remain
attractive. At the business review in April we expect the CEO to deliver a robust defence
of the roadside business. This should renew confidence that the core business will be
well-invested, stabilised and have an appealing membership proposition. The insurance
business could also be poised to deliver meaningful growth. Over FY19/20e – despite the
investment programme – we forecast debt pay-down of £75/100m worth ~7.5/10% to
equity p.a., improving to c£140m in FY21/22e (+14% p.a.). Factoring in modest EBITDA
growth (mainly driven by insurance) takes total equity returns to greater than 20%. We lower our
price target from 270p to 200p, applying an unchanged 10.5x EV/EBITDA multiple to our
10% lower CY19e EBITDA forecast.

BE11:49am

Target 200p.

Optimist Thanks BE
DM11:49am

There is also the small matter of price. Autoaid offers full service for a married couple at £43/year.

Pharma I get breakdown cover with my current account. Cheaper, and I don't have to call every year to get the "introductory" price. Wonder how much that and the trend to lease (with built-in cover) has shrunk their potential market.
LegalEagle Ireland - Central Bank of Ireland - cost to date €1bn of which €316m in redress. "By the end of 2017, lenders have been forced to pay €316 million in redress and compensation to those affected, with more to follow. This is as a direct result of the work of the Central Bank’s tracker mortgage examination. "
casapinos @DM can they specify married?
FATDAZ Still feel that AA and Saga might be a fit or at least a fast track to dual euthanasia
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Hm .... this all looks heroic for a company whose decline is cyclical, competitive and structural, the balance sheet as stretched tighter than a snaredrum and the management is in (comprehensively reported) turmoil.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian No mention of margins on shift from business under new car sales vs private cover! I would expect business to be less certain but margins to increase.
Tsetse Talking of AA, has anyone noticed that fewer teenagers are learning to drive these days? As in, a lot fewer
Jamie Chisholm Quite right Dan. Basic rule: never buy a re-float after Private Equity has sucked all the entrepreneurship out of a company and loaded it with debt. These IPOs should be shunnred
rwl GBP-USD what a climb! What is this down to?
BE11:52am

Okay, so it looks unlikely to breach Class A covenants because of the way they're arranged. But is that a buy case? I can't see it.

Soundbuy @Tsetse - you don't live in the sticks I take it.........
Swedish chef Get roadside, world travel, and four phone insurances for £7 month with Nationwide current account if you leave £2.5k in it. Also visa rates on foreign ATM withdrawals. Why does anyone pay for separate policies?
FATDAZ @legal eagle a I wonder what the states revenue was in income tax etc over that period of excess
undefined
CS1 @ Pharma: AA are offering me breakdown cover for £20 on a house/contents insurance quite
CS1 quote
11:52 am
DM11:52am

(Hello Jamie Thumbs up)

Tom Dalgleish As a tympanist I see upside
DM11:53am

Anything else around?

DJ any update IWG please?
Lefevre Good story "ONS’s crossed telecom wires raise questions over inflation figures". quite how official ONS figures thought this is a mystery: "Official data show the prices of telecoms goods and services were flat between 2010 and 2015"
BE11:53am

Um ..... plenty of results .........

RA rwl maybe risk of US governemtn closure?
SoS chemring a bit of a yo-yo today, results/fraud squad
Pharma @CS1, how much would you be overpaying on the house insurance? Never found them competitive.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian You are probably right guys on the PE vultures. I bought a small holding because the company is more than just the PE vultures.T here are other decent stakeholders and maybe brand strength will once again shine through. A sad story for a once decent brand!
FATDAZ @RWL re GBP lack of neg sentiment a weakish dollar and a short squeeze
hedgehog Iwg tomorrow ?
Lemmy Squeeky time on IWG, hopefully ROTR saw FT article online yesterday pm
11:54 am
BE11:54am

@DJ asks about IWG ......

bluesky @Tsetse - yup. Getting ready for autonomous cars perhaps?
FitzLions @wayneJ, not necessarily. It depends on whether the the case or the out of court settlement is significant enough to be regarded as price sensitive/inside information which is required to be disclosed.
wayneJ SAGA + AA => a looonggg SAAAGAAA?

In terms of the evergreen breakup theory, Alison Brittain just repeated the October guidance.

BE11:59am

[W]e have a broad and a management team, which is very open, and openly discusses the structure of the group on a regular basis. We are absolutely in step with all of our shareholders who look to us to increase shareholder value over, not just the short term, but the medium and long term as well. And so we are always open to debate some discussions about what is the best way of doing that. But nothing else has changed in our thinking at this stage. We are about halfway through transformation program in Costa that will deliver significant shareholder value and a very -- a much more efficient underpinned platform for that business to go forward and which will also deliver the foundation for any international business of scale. And so we are not wanting the management team to deviate from delivery of that program, which delivers great value, or to actually to be distracted from trading through a challenging environment and enabling those international strategies in China and in Express to gain the momentum that they need to.

Whitbread has reported like-for-like (LFL) sales growth of 0.3% and total sales growth of 5.6%. For H2, we are forecasting 1.0% LFL sales growth and total sales growth of 6.3%. 12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Premier Inn has delivered LFL sales growth of 0.5% and total sales growth of
5.0%. This is a further slowdown versus LFL sales growth of 3.5% in Q1 and 2.3%
in Q2. Occupancy for the quarter came in at 83.3%, which represented a
decrease from the same quarter last year of 84.5%. LFL RevPAR was down
1.5%, compared to the midscale and economy market of +0.6%, highlighting
particular softness in the London market. We are currently forecasting LFL
RevPAR growth for H2 of 1%. While a slowing in H2 RevPAR was expected as
the benefits from weaker sterling and resulting inbound tourism fades, the weaker
London market highlights risk to our full-year forecast.
